title: ramadan coronavirus muslims islam traditions mosques uk turkey egypt pakistan
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The&nbspmonth of spiritual contemplation will be very different for the majority&nbspof the&nbspworld’s 1.8 billion MuslimsOn the eve of Ramadan, 1.8 billion Muslims around the world are preparing for the month-long spiritual contemplation unlike ever before.Coronavirus has forced the hands of governments, with traditions that have stood for centuries&nbspunable to be observed due to lockdown&nbspmeasures&nbspaimed at containing&nbspthe spread of the pathogen. Emphasising devotion while fasting and developing an affinity with fellow Muslims, this time would usually see gatherings at mosques, homes and out on&nbspthe streets.But widespread restrictions have been implemented around the world, including a ban in Turkey on tents designed to offer&nbspfree fast-breaking iftar dinners and pre-dawn suhoor meals. Citizens there are also forbidden&nbspfrom tipping drummers walking through the streets to wake people for their last meal before dawn, with the country responding after nearly&nbsp100,000 cases and 2,259 fatalities as of Wednesday afternoon, according to Johns Hopkins University.&nbspCharity tables have also been barred in Egypt, though there have been just&nbsp3,490 cases with&nbspthe death total currently at 264.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSaudi Arabia has suspended visas for Muslims seeking to take pilgrimages to Mecca and Medina, while Iranian President Hassan Rouhani&nbspwas apologetic&nbspafter&nbspannouncing a ban on the country’s&nbspusual ceremonies and forbidding the public from&nbspattending holy shrines and mosques for two more weeks at least. Pakistan has walked back restrictions on&nbspgroups of five or less able to&nbspattend prayers at mosques though after&nbspclashes between&nbspworshipers and police.A sombre mood is likely to overshadow much of the month, though the nature of Islam could help Muslims cope better in these&nbsptesting circumstances.“It’s going to be different and difficult in certain circumstances, but Islam is a very flexible religion, it covers for all circumstances, so the usual worship we would do in mosques, we can do them at home, there’s no harm in that given the situation,”&nbspFarhad Ahmad, an Imam&nbspat Fazl Mosque in London, tells The Independent.“During Ramadan we increase our worship, doing more goodness towards others, paying more to charity. So in a way, given everybody is now at home already, you’re self-isolating or in quarantine, that is sort of a natural phenomena that usually happens in Ramadan anyway, as people become more devout and less social anyway.“It’s a bit different to what some people think about Ramadan. Being forced into it is not the ideal situation, Ramadan doesn’t say don’t go to work or see your friends, but at the same time, there’s an emphasis to reflect on life, spend more time worshipping God, so this opportunity has made us more aware that we can do this more comfortably.”Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastIndeed the practice of itikaf – solitary confinement during&nbspthe final days of Ramadan in a mosque – means that many Muslims may be accustomed to their current circumstances, even if they are now at home rather than a place of worships. While many&nbspmosques are now putting on&nbsponline&nbspexercise classes and lectures to the burden on people&nbspduring this time.“Some people are going through a difficult time with anxiety, depression or mental health issues,” Mr Ahmad adds. “But if you’re unwell or ill, Islam says you’re not supposed to fast. There are a lot of challenges, but because Islam is flexible, it allows you to manage in any circumstance.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Ahmad does concede there is “concern” about&nbspEid-al-Fitr, the festival to mark the end of fasting, which will now be “a completely different experience” given&nbspmany will be deprived globally&nbspfrom travelling to be with their families.Indonesian President Joko Widodo&nbsphas already banned the mudik, the term used for the annual exodus from towns and cities at Eid, claiming&nbsp”the relevant preparation needs to be done” in the world’s biggest Muslim-majority country, which has 7,418 cases and 635 fatalities to date.It is a similar experience back&nbspin the UK after the&nbspMosques and Imams National Advisory Board confirmed Islamic buildings will continue to remain closed throughout the entirety of Ramadan, claiming&nbspmass gatherings for night prayers would be&nbsp“extremely irresponsible”.“It would be deemed extremely irresponsible to congregate for night prayers or hold religious gatherings during this Ramadan in any mosque or houses with people who are not members of the immediate household,” said Qari Asim, a Leeds imam and chair of the board. “During the epidemic, the desire to perform prayers with a congregation in a mosque comes second title: figures show lockdown is starting work
story: THE future of this country depends on decisions made by ministers in the weeks and months ahead.If they relax restrictions too soon, thousands more Brits will lose loved ones before their time.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Butlockdown goes on for too long, the creaking economy will finally croak — leaving millions destitute.Which is why now is the wrong moment for aggressive finger-pointing.Yes, Britain’s initial reaction to the outbreak was far from perfect. Public Health England was embarrassingly underprepared, and it’s quite possible that ministers or their scientic advisers were too blase.But we are where we are. And brave, wise, le-saving decisions are made by confident politicians at the very top of their game — not terried men and women looking over their shoulders and worrying how they’ll be judged at a massively expensive public inquiry.The Government’s lockdown strategy is backed by an overwhelming majority of the public. And the figures show that it’s starting to work. Let’s cut the backseat driving and let Boris and his team get on with it.THE PPE crisis unfolding in hospitals and care homes shames this nation.Britain has the raw materials to kit out staff. Sothe Government and private companies worked effectively together, we have no doubt that our NHS heroes could get the protection they need.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThere has been little explanation of why deals between firms and the Government haven’t been made quickly and effectively.It leaves Britain at the mercy of foreign countries. And the consequences are deadly.When a bunch of box packers at an airport in Turkey make a mistake, our frontline staff are left high and dry.We’ve never been fans of pointless bureaucracy. And when our doctors, nurses and carers are at risk, something has to give. Fast.WE couldn’t be more proud of the great British public.For four weeks, we’ve been cooped up indoors while the sunshine blazes through the window. But — with the exception of a few covidiots — we’ve resisted temptation and stuck to the rules.And our tremendous efforts weren’t in vain. According to one top scientist, Britain is over the first peak.That doesn’t mean we’re out of the woods yet. If we gave up now, we’d face a second wave and another crippling lockdown which thousands of British companies simply couldn’t survive.Butwe hold tight, there really is light at the end of the tunnel.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking readers to sign the petition online at thesun georgecrossfornhs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trevor kavanagh public health england
story: WE are all pulling together following the rules, helping our neighbours, applauding the NHS – a genuinely United Kingdom.But the blame game is already in full swing.Labour’s vow to avoid playing party politics with a global emergency has bitten the dust, with Boris Johnson effectively accused of leaving voters to die.But it’s the Opposition’s job to oppose and politicians are paid to take the flak.Broadcasters and newspapers, including our Sunday Times stablemate, are piling in with suggestions Boris has been fiddling while Rome burned.They claim the PM was skiving on five-day weeks while spending weekends at Chevening, a “grace-and- favour country retreat” in Kent, instead of tackling the incoming apocalypse.As the earliest reports of the disease were reaching the West, the idle blighter was “sunning himself” on the luxury island of Mustique with pregnant fiancée Carrie Symonds.This, remember, was after the longest war of political attrition ever seen in a hostile House of Commons and an exhausting General Election where Boris scored a landslide victory.Nobody in Europe or America was raising the Covid- alarm at this time.As French President Emanuel Macron admitted last week, the entire Western world was caught on the hop. His government has “made mistakes” — and so has ours.But presidents and prime ministers have a lot on their plates. When it comes to health alarms, they rely on experts.It would take a very brave prime minister indeed to ignore the people appointed to safeguard the nation’s health when lives are at risk.And the advice from those experts — the sprawling Public Health England in particular — was that Britain faced no more than a larger-than-usual dose of winter flu.PHE was against German-style mass testing and, when caught flat-footed, rejected help from commercial laboratories in providing those tests.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment — including masks, gowns and gloves — despite a  test run showing these were a priority.PHE dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators for intensive-care patients and extra hospital beds.Frequently when running short of crucial gear, PHE resisted offers of outside help, leaving the NHS scrambling to catch up.And when it came to opening London’s ,-bed Nightingale emergency hospital, it was the Army that did the job in nine days.It was also PHE who insisted the British public would be protected by “herd immunity”.The sooner  per cent of the population had contracted the virus and become immune, the better, it said.Boris faithfully followed their lead until another expert, Prof Neil Ferguson, issued a nightmare prediction of , dead unless Britain was locked up overnight.It was Ferguson who in the Blair years forecast mass burials on the scale of the Great Plague during the “Mad Cow” scare and the foot-and-mouth outbreak.Neither Armageddon scenario came remotely close.Once this is over and the inevitable inquiry is held, Boris and his government will inevitably be in the dock.So will PHE, a fiercely territorial quango with a giant £.billion budget.Much of this goes on pay and perks for well-cushioned executives, with  staff on six-figure salaries — a nanny-state rich list.Its website boasts its job is to “protect and improve the nation’s health and wellbeing”.And yet this box-ticking bureaucracy — obsessed with sugary drinks and ersity — has failed at the first hurdle.It shares with the higher reaches of the NHS a suspicion of fleet-footed commercial rivals and deep-seated hostility to the “profit motive”.Criticism, still muted, is widespread within the medical community, including frontline doctors and consultants.Every Thursday at pm, a grateful nation stands and applauds NHS staff working around the clock to save lives at the risk of their own.The same cannot be said for the inflexible, politically correct quango that binds the hands of medical staff in the name of an outdated socialist credo on health provision: State good, private bad.Much will need to change after Covid-. And that change must start with Public Health England.MINISTERS are looking at a traffic-light system to lt lockdown. Red for Stop, green for Go, with amber in between.Overzealous cops and councils are being reined in. ­Common sense is taking over. Families can now attend funerals.We might be able to say goodbye to dying ­relatives. Parks will reopen to the ­public. Benches have been deemed safe to sit on.So how about allowing non-contact sporting activities that boost both physical and mental health Swimming pools are surely safe. title: coronavirus pandemic freedom britain orwell
story: IMAGINE a Britain where everyone dutully carries an identity card and the Government tracks the movements of all its terried citizens.It is a bleak world of curfews and crackdowns, of mass surveillance and monitoring systems - with facial recognition cameras looming over every street corner. In public spaces, loudspeakers blare out official safety messages. On each phone there is an app that reports back to the authorities on the users’ health and online activities.Nor is there any escape in the home. The very concept of privacy barely exists when the state can use sophisticated technology to keep watch on our behaviour.This vision sounds like a nightmare, but it could become all too real thanks to the coronavirus.In its fallout, Covid- may end up causing as much damage to our essential freedoms as to our health - with the new menace of Big Brother on its way.Already the current emergency has led to the first comprehensive lockdown in British history.Evenit has been necessary to slow the spread of the virus, it is nevertheless a draconian measure that would have been unthinkable only a few weeks ago.Effectively the entire public has been placed under house arrest.Normal le has been brought juddering to a halt, while the police have been given unprecedented powers to enforce the quarantine.Even sitting for too long on a park bench or taking a leisurely drive have become offences against the state.With heroic stoicism, the vast majority of people have accepted this policy, seeing it as the only realistic means to protect the NHS and lessen the transmission of coronavirus.They hope that once the worst of the crisis has passed, there will be ato the Britain that they love, where inidual rights are respected and the power of the state is limited.Above all, this is my deepest wish too - though the chances look slim.One of the reasons why I, as an Irishman, admire this country so much is because of the British tradition of liberty, reflected in Magna Carta, parliamentary democracy and the defeat of Nazi tyranny.Unfortunately, even when the current lockdown is lted, it is possible that heavy-handed control by the state will remain.Quarantine may be temporary, but authoritarianism could be permanent.This is because officialdom, shaken by the unexpected scale of the coronavirus crisis, will be determined to prevent its resurgence by any means necessary.That will involve far more than just the maintenance of social distancing and the wearing of face masks.An arsenal of other measures could be deployed in the fight.One will be the reintroduction of curfews at the first sign of any new flare up in cases.If there is such a setback, the mood of the authorities will be even more intolerant towards any breaches. Fines will be heavier, jail terms longer.The skies will be filled with the sound of helicopters and the sight of drones as police — or even the Army — embark on ruthless enforcement.Another change is likely to be the advent of biometric identity cards, backed up by a comprehensive database of the entire population.Such a system has long been the dream of bureaucrats in Whitehall, and the aftermath of the crisis provides the perfect excuse for its imposition.Its appeal is all the greater because the latest type of cards operate with biotechnology that scans eyes and fingerprints.Only last year, the European Union passed a regulation requiring all national identity card systems on the continent to comply with new biometric standards.The British state will not stop there in its new crusade.In the name of health protection, mobile phone companies could be required to share data on their clients.According to the New Statesman, British Telecom, which owns the EE network, is already “in talks with the Government about handing over phone location and usage data” for the purpose of monitoring adherence to the lockdown.Similarly, tracking apps on devices could also be made obligatory so that the Government will be able to trace the contacts of anyone infected and ensure compliance with quarantine rules.Just as some criminals on release have to wear electronic tags, anyone who has tested positive for the virus may be ordered to wear a medical wristband even when self-isolation is over.Alternatively, those who test negative could be given immunity certicates.These initiatives will be accompanied by a political drive to reinforce support for the state, as happens in wartime.In a distinctly un-British way, people will be encouraged to snitch on those who fail to abide by the rules.Challenges to ruling orthodoxy will be seen as a form of subversion.If that sounds far-fetched, consider how laws to tackle discrimination or terrorism are now used to uphold fashionable ideology, as highlighted in the outrageous recent case where Lincolnshire businessman Harry Miller was questioned by police for allegedly sending a “transphobic” tweet.In the new Britain scarred by corona, the whole relationship between the state and the public will be inverted.The Government is meant to be accountable to the people.But, burdened with ID cards, curfews and tracking apps, the people will be accountable to the Government.There is an echo here of the George Orwell’s novel , which painted a terrying picture of Britain under totalitarian rule.In Orwell’s society gripped by permanent crisis, the citizenry were monitored day and night by the state.The propaganda and all-seeing eye of Big Brother could never be avoided, “always watching and the voice enveloping you, asleep or awake, indoors or outdoors, in the bath or in bed.In the present global crisis, many look to the experience of Asia, which has had far lower Covid death rates than the West.But that is a dangerous stance. First it ignores the fundamental point that China is responsible for the spread of this disease through its cover-up, persecution and lies.The country should be in the dock, not garnered with praise.Second it glosses over the oppressive nature of many of these Asian regimes, particularly that run by the tyrannical Chinese communist party.China has eagerly embraced new technology, like tracking devices, facial recognition cameras, eye-scanning security barriers and online data gathering, precisely because they drastically enhance the power of the state machine.Indeed, the country likes to boast that it is building the “world’s largest camera surveillance network”.As an example, in Guangzhou province, the commercial hub of southern China, tablets have been recently installed on buses to promote safety.Passengers are expected to lean their foreheads close to the tablet so that their photos and temperatures can be taken.China is also establishing a sinister “social credit system”, where behaviour is monitored to assess a citizen’s trustworthiness.Those given high ratings by the state can receive rewards like employment offers, shorter waiting times in hospitals and discounts at hotels.It is a recipe for bureaucratic despotism and political infantilisation.Other Asian nations, while nothing like as cruel as China, are also using technology as a tool to corral their public.Hong Kong has introduced mandatory wristbands for those in quarantine so they can be tracked.Taiwan has a monitoring system known as “the electronic fence” where those who are meant to be in isolation will be visited by the authoritiesthey turn off their mobiles.In South Korea, the government gathers huge amounts of data from phone records, CCTV images, and credit cards to help track citizens during the Covid crisis, while in Singapore, phone users are encouraged to download the “TraceTogether” app.This keeps a record of all the other numbers that have been in close proximity to the smartphone, making it easier to trace anyone who might have been near the owner in the event of a positive Covid-test.Not all of these developments are bad, provided they are genuinely used as weapons against disease rather than vehicles for the expansion of state power.But we have seen since   how the excuse of security can be used as a cover for bullying by the authorities, with the result that international air travel is often a miserable experience.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.We should not allow the same to happen on a national scale in the wake of the pandemic.As the great author C.S.Lewis wrote: “Of all tyrannies, a tyranny exercised for the good of its victims may be the most oppressive.It would be better to live under robber barons than omnipotent moral busybodies.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ramadan 2020 when start timetable
story: Heres everything you need to know.Ramadan marks the month when the Quran was revealed to Prophet Muhammad by Allah .Ramadan will see Muslims around the world fasting during daylight hours for  days.All Muslims who have reached puberty are expected to fast during Ramadan, although there are some exceptions, including women who are menstruating or pregnant, and those suffering from illness.The rules mean food and drink, including water, are not allowed during daylight hours for the entire month. Smoking and sex are also banned.The month is traditionally viewed as an opportunity for devotion, reflection and celebration of the mercy and love of Allah , while the fasting ritual aids reflection on the suffering of others.Those observing the fast are encouraged to read the Quran and the holy text is recited at the Tarawih, special nightly prayers that would normally be held at mosques throughout the month but cant this year due to coronavirus.Coronavirus lockdown has hit all religions hard, with services and places of worship being shut down and moved online.Ramadan  is due to start today, April , in the evening.The Islamic calendar is based around the lunar cycle, the Holy month of Ramadan rotates by approximately ten days each year.The month is confirmed with the sighting of the new moon.Suhoor is the first meal of the day, a quick snack before fasting begins.Starting at .am on day one. Suhoor then happens roughly two minutes earlier every day.Iftar Magrib is when Muslims break fasting with a light meal and some water before having a proper dinner.This happens at sunset and will get later as the month progresses.Fasting will last between  hours and  minutes, and  hours and  minutes come Eid.You can find a more detailed timetable for your area here.Ramadan in the UK is predicted to end at pm exactly on May .Muslims celebrate with a massive -hour party involving family and friends called the feast of Eid al-Fitr.This celebration is marked with lights, decorations and gts, with worshippers often dressing up and decorating their homes.Sadly,lockdown is still in place by then, these parties will have to be familial events, or will need to take place online through video chats.The MCB is offering guidance on how to organise virtual tars online with loved ones and members of the community via video chat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan boycotting publicity
story: Begging the question: Will any of us actually notice For, despite largely positive coverage by the pro-monarchy outlets in question, this self-aggrandising couple have barely engaged with them on any level beyond sending threatening legal letters.So they could have just continued as normal and skipped the part where, yet again, they create a drama when none exists while simultaneously claiming that they want to live a quiet le.But all that aside, it was the timing of their breathtakingly imperious statement that really stank.The world is in lockdown, trying to combat a killer virus, people are dying in their thousands, others are losing their businesses or jobs and young people are struggling to cope with being cooped up away from their friends.So what do the self-appointed King and Queen of mental health issues do  Once again they try to pull focus and make it all about them.On top of that, the decision to release it on the eve of the Queen’s official th birthday meant that the next day’s headlines were dominated by the Sussexes’ childish, “I’m not talking to you any more” declaration.Bless them, they even sent it tonewspaper, which has remained on their approved list of media outlets despite wanting to scrap the monarchy upon which their ever-dwindling kudos is based.It resists writing much about the Sussexes because it regards them as largely irrelevant, not because it’s showing deference to their, er, greatness, by toeing whatever PR line they’re churning out on any given week.Meanwhile, the pro-royal newspapers and, more importantly, their collective millions of readers, have been placed on the naughty step.But then, as the Queen’s former, long-running adviser Dickie Arbiter — who has known Harry since he was four — put it: “Prince Harry is not the brightest bunny on the planet.”It was all going so well, wasn’t it For a multitude of reasons — among them his launch of the inspiring Invictus games — Harry was always our favourite royal by a country mile.But despite a glorious and much-celebrated wedding day and glowing coverage of his first official tour with his new we, his “cheeky chappie” demeanour changed and he seemingly became more brooding and bitter, particularly towards the newspapers his more media-savvy mother had actively courted.Today, “the media” is an all-encompassing term that includes not just newspapers and magazines, but rolling news channels, websites and the ubiquitous “social media” that, one suspects, Harry just lumps together as one single irritant.A journalist, who spent time with him for an article, revealed that he reads everything written about him and Meghan, which — as anyone in the public eye will tell you — is the route to madness.Far better to view gossipy, rather than wholly factual, stories asthey were one of those Amaretti biscuit wrappers you set fire to in restaurants — something that burns brightly for mere moments before vaporising into the ether.If Harry applied that philosophy, he’d find his mental health would improve markedly.But instead he has turned his legal guns on four tabloid newspapers for “distorted,  or invasive beyond reason” coverage with-out providing a single example.Newspapers do get things wrong occasionally, but there are checks and balances in place for corrections and, of course, laws too.The internet, by comparison, is the Wild West.But hey ho. As I say, this baffling statement will make zero dference to their already fractured relationship with the UK.In an ideal world, every media outlet worldwide would form a pact that they will never again write about or use a photograph of the Sussexes.The effect would be swt and damning.For without the oxygen of publicity, what are they Married to a home-body, I have always rather envied those whose other halves travel frequently for their job.It gives you the house to yourself sporadicallyand makes you appreciate them when they .But in lockdown we are faring well because we are already used to being together most of the time.A friend whose husband usually travels for work called me the other day to say that his sudden, constant presence in the home was causing friction.And yesterday, Boyzone star Shane Lynch announced the sad news that lockdown has put his -year marriage to Sheena White under intolerable strain.He says: “I’m not even in my family home right now because me and her were at each other’s throats.“It wasn’t a good time or a good space.“I’m usually on the road and for the first time I’ve spent three months in my house . . . it can be a struggle.”Indeed it can. Let’s hope they sort it out for the sake of their two children.Now the dust has settled around Professor Neil Ferguson’s original estimate of , Covid deaths, it’s perhaps time to stand back and take a logical overview of the situation.While the death toll is still worrying, the mantra that we are critically harming the economy to protect the NHS from being overwhelmed is undermined by the news that many of the private hospitals repurposed for Covid patients are lying virtually empty and the ,-bed facility set up in London’s ExCel centre is only treating  people.It’s adding credence to the burgeoning mindset that, perhaps, those who are considered vulnerable should remain in lockdown while the rest of the country makes a gradualto school or work while maintaining strict social distancing measures.On GMB yesterday, a gruff, Swedish professor, whose name escaped me, was asked to explain the thinking behind his country’s policy to keep everything open.He replied: “People are not stupid.”In other words, the Swedes are taking personal responsibility for how they behave and, as of earlier this week, the death rate was starting to decline.It remains to be seen whether Sweden’s outlier stance proves to be the correct one, but one thing is for certain: Its economy may be weakened at the end of it, but it won’t be on the critical list like ours.Model and businessman David Gandy talked about the importance of fostering at the weekend, under the headline, “OMG. He’s so cute!”Indeed he is, was my immediate thought. My second was that I would happily foster him anytime.However, it turns out the headline and suggestion of benevolence was aimed at Dora, his rescue pup from Battersea Dogs Home, for which David is an ambassador.He says: “What I love about the evenings now is the calmness of a tired, sleeping dog at your side. I watch Dora dreaming.”Lucky Dora.One wondersshe knows that, when it comes to good fortune, she has won the canine equivalent of the Lottery.Last year, I read to kids in a primary school and, with rare exception, every time I asked what they wanted to be when they grew up, they replied: “A YouTuber.”Yet last week, while queuing behind a mother and her daughter outside the supermarket, the young girldeclared her desire to become a nurse when she left school.Now that is something positive to come out of the Covid- crisis.Jigsaws are getting me through the long days of lockdown.Despite The Bloke’s lame attempts to hide the last pieceI completed my fth at the weekend and, as an exercise in mindfulness, it’s right up there with any yoga retreat.So imagine my joy when Kodak announced last week that it has produced the world’s largest jigsaw with, gulp, , pieces.It is  separate images of world landmarks and, when finished, covers  square metres – about the size of a standard living room. Sadly, it also costs £, so I’ll stick to my ,-piece cheapies. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus matt hancock testing fiasco
story: WE sympathise with Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary unenviably copping the flak for every Covid setback. But he has to stop spinning and be honest.Let us say first, though, that he is right to rejoice that the NHS and its increased capacity has coped so far with this catastrophe. And that the nation HAS heeded the call to protect it and save lives.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealIn fact we have gone far further, raising millions for NHS staff via hero Captain Tom Moore and The Sun’s Who Cares Wins appeal — while big-hearted volunteers are working flat-out to sew together much-needed PPE and scrubs.And it is potentially fantastic news that human vaccine trials start in Oxford on Thursday, an amazing feat given that these processes normally take years.Those are all positives.But Mr Hancock should stop pretending his testing strategy is anything but a fiasco.Tests are going DOWN.He promised , a day by next Thursday.Why  It merely set him up for humiliation.Andwe can now carry out , a day, why are only , done Why are NHS staff forced to travel huge distances to a testing centre, only to be turned away Why aren’t far, far more being testedthe capacity exists On PPE, why announce huge new stocks before they are in hand Or sit for weeks on solid offers from UK suppliers On masks, why claim to be still evaluating the “science” on their effectiveness, when they are already vital in hospitals and care homes and routinely worn abroad The Government really just wants to prevent a public stampede when NHS staff need them more.This crisis is grim enough without people feeling misled by those they are trusting to see us through it.THE petrol price rip-off is laid bare as never before.For the first time, oil costs less than nothing. Yes, you read that right.Is fuel plummeting on our forecourts  Of course not.Retailers say they cannot afford that, because they’re still flogging petrol and diesel bought at higher ­prices. What self-serving rubbish.If the wholesale cost was soaring, pump prices would rocket in minutes.It’s true that a chunk of the fuel price is tax. And far fewer of us are filling up.But many ARE still having to drive to work and carry out essential deliveries.FairFuelUK want a new watchdog to ensure fair prices for ever. We agree.Drivers are sick of being taken for a ride.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.LET us salute Admiral, the car insurers.They know we’re not driving or making claims, so they’re voluntarily refunding £ per policy . . . or £million in all.Quite right.Insurers shouldn’t be cashing in on economic armageddon.When will their rivals step up too A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog best friend youll ever have
story: THE ten million dogs in the UK never felt more like man’s best friend than they do in these lockdown days.When death and suffering are all around, when there is so much anxiety and fear everywhere, owning a dog can’t fail to put a smile on your face, a spring in your step and a lust for le in your heart.Separated from our friends, family and so much of what constitutes normal le, having one keeps ten million of us sane.It is hard to feel too sorry for yourself when there is a man’s best friend gazing up at you asyou are the greatest thing in the world.And it is hard to feel down for very long when you see how glad your dog is just to be alive.They are the best personal trainers in the world.Unlike a gym, walking your pet is not optional. You have to do it.They keep us fit — or at least, far fitter than we would ever bethey weren’t compulsory walkies waiting for us at the startof every new day.I would never dream of jumping out of bed at dawnit was not for Stan, our ruby-coloured, eight-year-old Cavalier King Charles spaniel, who is always keen to get out into the world and snf a few lampposts, greet four-legged friends and wander, blissed-out, through nature.Whatever the weather, Stan wakes up ready for his dawn yomp on London’s Hampstead Heath and, whatever my mood, Stan is sure to lt it.Because dogs are the most positive creatures on God’s earth.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealNo animal on the planet comes in so many dferent shapes and sizes and temperaments, but every dog knows how to get the maximum joy out of any given moment.Dogs have a genius for living le to the full.In these dark days, their relentlessly positive outlook is nothing less than inspirational.And you can’t help noticing that dogs rather like lockdown.With her A-levels coming up, the closure of the schools was a devastating blow for my -year-old daughter.But Stan is absolutely delighted to have her hanging around the house.Even after all these weeks, he trots after her with his tail wagging happily and a pleasantly surprised expression that says: “What are you doing here in the middle of the day ”Many of our ten million pooches must get desperately lonely home alone during the long working days of normal le.They are not lonely now, and are delighted to be our constant companions.The reason that the ,-year-old partnership between humans and dogs has worked so well is because dogs have been happy to perform whateverwe have asked of them.Guard dogs, guide dogs, snfer dogs, herding dogs, lapdogs, therapy dogs — you name it and some dog out there will do it brilliantly.And now there is research to seethey can be trained to spot coronavirus.Medical detection dogs already help screen for cancer, malaria and Parkinson’s disease.Now the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine is running tests to seedogs can be trained to snf out Covid-.“We do not knowCovid- has a specic odour yet,” says Professor James Logan, head of LSHTM’s department for disease control.“But we know that other respiratory diseases change our body odour so there is a chance that it does.“Andit does, dogs will be able to detect it.”We ask a lot of our dogs.In the lockdown, we look to our four-legged friends to be the cure for loneliness.We are backing a proposal by Lord Ashcroft to honour our health heroes with the gallantry gong given for acts of bravery that did not take place in battle.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.The Dogs Trust, the UK’s largest canine charity, reports that is has been “overwhelmed” with applications for dogs to keep the nation company during lockdown, not least for all those millions of children who are shut out of school and no longer able to see their friends.“On Sunday March  we recorded our busiest day at the contact centre since it opened in , with a  per cent increase in calls,” says a Dogs Trust spokesman. “However, like many other animal welfare charities, we have now closed all our rehoming centres.”This dog-crazy nation got even crazier about dogs during lockdown.But it is probably just as well that organisations such as the Dogs Trust and Battersea Dogs Home are currently closed.Because getting a dog should never be an impulse buy.I came downstairs this morning and discovered Stan had sprayed liquid diarrhoea all over his cage.He was mortied, not least because he knew that I was going to have to clean it up. Stan can’t do it.Nobody will ever love you like a dog.Nobody will ever be as happy to see you as a dog.Nobody will ever make you laugh as much as a dog.In their heartbreakingly brief lives they make you realise how lucky you are to be alive.I would recommend getting a dog to anyone.Watching your child grow up with a dog is a privilege and a joy.But our dogs rely on us as much as we rely on them.And a dog is for ever, not just for lockdown.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: terrifying moment birds prey three poodles through apartment window
story: Gabriela Leonardi, who owns the three French poodles, initially posted the video to TikTok before it was widely shared by Spanish media.In the video, the pair of condors can be seen landing on the penthouse balcony railings after spotting the pups.The three dogs bark excitedly as the gigantic birds size them up from outside the window.One of the condors moves down the railings in order to get closer to the pups but the glass window continues to separate the predator from the prey.The condor begins to peck the window in an attempt to get at one of the dogs.Ms Leonardi is convinced the birds are harmless and only want to play with her pets.She said: #The condors come here quite a lot at the moment, the video of them playing with the dogs that everyone is talking about is from a month ago, but especially since the lockdown they have certainly been him more frequently.#Gabriela said that about two years ago the larger of the birds, a male, been spotted outside her home but that later he had been joined by a female and then the third bird had started turning up as well.She admitted it was much more frequent since the lockdown and has even given the water to drink.The pet owner is also giving them scraps from her barbecue.Condors across the city have been left hungry due to the departure of people from the local streets from the coronavirus lockdown.In the wild, Condors prefer to eat carrion, Andean condors have been noted to sometimes hunt small live animals such as birds, rabbits and rodents.According to local media, the birds of prey are struggling to survive in the city as people stay at home during the pandemic.Across the world, wild animals have been venturing out into the streets which have been left deserted due to the virus.In the UK, deers have taken over the deserted East London streets as they make the most of the coronavirus lockdown.The deer were pictured catching some rays on a grassy area in front of a row of houses as locals obeyed government lockdown rules.In the US, multiple Twitter-users have spotted coyotes roaming the streets of San Francisco during the three-week lockdown.In Benidorm, a colony of seagulls were spotted preying on an elderly shopper who was carrying their shopping.Locals claimed online the aggressive birds have now taken to attacking people on brief trips for groceries in the ghost town resort.Their normal source of food is said to have vanished after bars and restaurants were shut.

title: britain eu medical supply scheme
story: The EU Commission today contradicted Nos claims that the UK only failed to take part because it didnt receive an email invitation.It said the plan to pool procurement of key kit including ventilators and PPE had been a recurring topic at virtual meetings British officials attended.A spokesman said: The UK was aware of the work that was ongoing and had ample opportunity to express its wish to participate.Why it did not do so is something on which we cannot comment.The statement will further ignite the debate over withdrawn claims from the Foreign Offices top mandarin Sir Simon McDonald that a political decision was made not to take part.Care minister Helen Whately today stuck to the Government line and blamed the fact that “an email went astray” for the mix-up.And the PMs title: real opposition labour civil service
story: FOR three long years our civil servants did everything they possibly could to prevent the UK from leaving the European Union.In other words, to thwart the will of the people — and the policies of our democratically elected Government.Hell, they almost succeeded, too.Civil service insiders report that the organisation was, almost to a man, openly hostile to Brexit.Derisive of the referendum.Civil service reports into the effects of Brexit whipped up the worries.Civil servants leaked whatever they could do to the Press.Not least the foreign Press.And now, in the midst of the coronavirus crisis, guess what  Yup, they’re still doing it.Britain’s top diplomat Sir Simon McDonald, one of the highest-paid people in the public sector, has tried to shaft the Government over Brexit and the virus.He said that the Government took a “political decision” not to join an EU effort to buy protective equipment and ventilators.This was wholly untrue, as the Foreign Secretary, Dominic Raab, angrily made clear.McDonald — still somehow in a job — was forced to back down.Two things. First, the EU scheme has spectacularly failed to deliver anything.Indeed — as I suggest below — the EU is coming apart at the seams over this virus.And second, the invitation to join the scheme was sent, by those EU genii, to the wrong address. Duh.It is becoming more apparent with every day that passes that the civil service is the biggest impediment to the UK reforming itself.It is hostile to the Government, to the people — and deeply hostile to change of any kind.It is a vast congregation of time-serving bureaucrats dedicated only to saving their own jobs.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealEven now, red tape may be stling our efforts to deal with the coronavirus.It will be interesting to discover, once this pandemic has receded, what part the civil service played in the UK’s failure to carry out adequate testing for the virus, right from the start.And the failure to bring in vital equipment.Government ministers carry the can for these sorts of failures, of course.But it is the civil service charged with enacting the decisions.I wonder how many ventilators have failed to arrive here because of some bureaucratic hitch I wonder what would have happenedthe civil service, rather than the military, were charged with building those Nightingale hospitals.They might just about be ready by the end of the century.It was clear, when this Government came to office, that the real opposition wasn’t the ragged hounds and trots on the Labour benches, but from the very people paid to enable the government — the civil service.There needs to be a clear-out, from the top down.Because this battle — between civil servants and Government ministers — will continue long after this virus has been defeated.Their opposition to Government policy hampers almost everything we do.That’s no way to run a country.I see The Vicar Of Dibley is back. Dawn French will reprise her role as the Rev Geraldine Granger for the BBC’s Big Night In this evening.That should cheer us up for a few moments.Here are a few more sitcoms they could update to keep us laughing through the lockdown:Some Mothers Do ’Ave ’Em – Frank Spencer is appointed Health Secretary and has to give briefings every day to the Press. Ooh, Betty, the hilarity.Till Death Us Do Part – Alf Garnett, in self isolation, kindly explains to us what he thinks of some Chinese culinary practices and the Chinese government.Both Feet In The Grave – sadly, there was no ventilator for Victor.Not Going Out – huge laughs as a large number of people don’t, er, go out.Are You Being Served  – um . . .  no, actually.Dad’s Army – Captain Mainwaring orders his men to build a new hospital in two days flat, with hilarious consequences.On The Buses – Stan and Jack vow to wreak revenge on the idiots who won’t give them PPE.How’s the home- schooling coming along then Got the kids up at eight every morning to do a bit of calculus I’ve been enjoying it, although I maybe haven’t given enough attention to mathematics.But it’s been a good chance to redress some of the crap my daughter has been subjected to in ten years of state education.She now has a slightly dferent take on the British Empire, the poverty of Africa and how fun it might be to transition into being a bloke.A mad woman in America has warned that home-schooling is “dangerous”. Why Professor of Law Elizabeth Bartholet said: “It’s always dangerous to put powerful people in charge of the powerless.”.She added that it gave parents “authoritarian control” over the kids.You mean like the authoritarian control they’ve had from the teachers all these years, love It’s comforting to know that even in this crisis, the liberals are still as deranged as ever.You’ve got to feel sorry for Victoria Beckham, haven’t you Poor woman says that last week was the worst of her le.She’s bitterly disappointed with you, the British people.She thinks we were all terribly arsey about her when she decided to use our money to furlough her fashion company workers.How could we be so mean as to expect a woman who has an estimated wealth of £million – acquired largely through singing badly – should dig into her own pockets.Rather than scrounging off the taxpayer.The stinking rich really don’t get it, do they No self awareness whatsoever – and even less shame.But then never mind the witless Posh, whose useless company loses millions every year.Look at old beardo Branson – Sir Richard, entrepreneur and “philanthropist”.He wants YOU to pay HIM £million to bail out his airline, Virgin.This is a man who has paid not a single penny of income tax in the UK for fourteen years.But when his company is in trouble he expects you to bail him out.And this from a bloke who has already been coining it from the taxpayer for his awful rail franchises.This kind of bare-faced cheek almost beggars belief.Or there’s Apple boss Tim Cook boasting about sending a few safety masks to the UK.SO kind of you, Tim.Now how about your company pays its proper share of tax in the UK  Then we might not need your charity.Pope Francis has pleaded with the EU for countries to “come together” to fight the virus.Ha. Fat chance, your Popeship.The European Union is falling apart as a consequence of this crisis.All the member states have been doing the sensible thing – and ignoring everything the EU bureaucrats have to say.Germany introduced very tough anti-immigration measures, for example.But the EU has been criticised for abandon- ing Spain and Italy.There are big rows over a joint debt fund to help the worst-hit countries.There are arguments over what phone app should be used to track virus carriers.One leading European economist said that the EU was in danger of “imploding”.Ah well – every cloud, huh I CAN’T get to my usual snippers in Saltburn. So my we and daughter kindly agreed to cut my hair for me. They gave me a kind of Mohican.I think it’s great. The new me. Liddle, back in the game. Watch out, chicks.KIM JONG-UN is apparently very ill. Nothing to do with the coronavirus.The morbidly obese weirdo who runs North Korea is thought to be under-going serious heart surgery.He’s getting his reward then, for eating like a king while the rest of his country starves. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus mask work shops transport lockdown 2021
story: THE Government is prepared to urge Brits to wear masks to avoid spreading coronavirus.It will recommend covering the face with something as simple as a scarf when at work, in shops or on public transport.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe Government’s top scientists met on Tuesday to decide on the face-covering move to help stop the coronavirus spread, amid fears that social distancing will roll into  and chances of a vaccine within a year are slim.Masking the mouth and nose limits asymptomatic people — who are infected but showing no symptoms — from passing on the disease by coughing or sneezing.It comes as Britain’s top doctor last night issued a bleak warning that the nation may have to live with tough social distancing measures for “the next calendar year”.Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty also stressed that the chances of a vaccine in the next year were “incredibly small”.He said: “In the long run, the exit from this is going to be one of two things, ideally.“A vaccine, and there are a iety of ways they can be deployed . . . or highly effective drugs so that people stop dying of this disease eventhey catch it.”But he added: “The probability of having those any time in the next calendar year are incredibly small and I think we should be realistic about that.“We’re going to have to rely on other social measures, which of course are very socially disruptive as everyone is finding at the moment.“But it’s going to take a long time.”The Sun exclusively revealed earlier this week that Brits should not expect to see ato normal le in .After weeks of debate, ministers are expected to issue the masking advice as soon as the weekend.The new guidance will be for any face-covering to be used, even just a scarf.It will apply to all who go into confined spaces with others where it is dficult to observe the two-metre distancing rule.But masks will not be needed in all public places such as parks or quiet streets.Compulsory orders to wear masks are not expected, though they may happen when the lockdown restrictions loosen.Experts from the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies met on Tuesday to consider key evidence.They think that, while masks will not stop Brits from catching the virus, they will help prevent them from spreading it.However it was stressed people will not be advised to wear medical-grade masks, to help the NHS.A Whitehall source said last night: “No decision is going to be made which would take medical masks away from the NHS. Everybody is very clear on that.“If you actually have symptoms you need to isolate, full stop.“A cloth mask is not a replacement for staying at home and nobody should think otherwise.”Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the Government is following SAGE advice, but will not be handing out free masks, as some other countries have.He added: “We have to make sure we have supplies available for health and care staff.”Prof Whitty also warned ministers today they face dficult “trade-offs” when they review the lockdown again by May , when the three-week extension ends.He said SAGE is working on options to ease some restrictions, but they will have downsides.None could happen until the rate of transmission ­— known as R — was below one person giving it to one other “at any point”.Prof Whitty added: “We have to be very realisticpeople are hoping it’s suddenly going to move from where we are in lockdown to where suddenly everything is gone.“That is a wholly unrealistic expectation.“If you release more on one area, you have to keep on board more of another area so there’s a proper trade-off.”He added: “It does not take very long from bad numbers to really bad numbers.”No  officials refer to what happens after May  as the “next phase”.A “suck-it-and-see” plan is being drawn up based on scientists’ data to see what restrictions to try easing first.One senior figure told The Sun: “We will try a bit at a time, and then pause, so we can see what effect that has on the transmission rate. Pace will be very gradual.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Some shops could be opened, or Brits told to go back to workthey stay a safe distance apart.Mr Hancock also said that mass “contact tracing” — where staff identy who the carrier has been near — may be just “weeks” away.He said it will help “control this virus with fewer of the very extraordinary social distancing measures that have been in place.”It was obvious that insisting on their use in confined spaces can help slow the spread of the virus, imperfect though they are.The nation must now rapidly start making our own. They’re not dficult and there are many designs, including ours on Page  of Thursdays newspaper. We must NOT deplete supplies of professionally produced kit for NHS or care staff who are in direct contact with Covid-positive patients.Masks, plus other measures including radical changes to working hours to avoid rush-hour crowds, will help lessen the spread when the lockdown is relaxed, as it must be soon.Let’s not kid ourselves: infections are still bound to increase. But there are no good options now. We cannot continue bankrupting Britain and shedding millions of jobs with this paralysis.We cannot wait for a vaccine, nor for “herd immunity” to be achieved via most of the active population getting the virus and recovering. Both look a mile off.A better bet is some new or repurposed antiviral drug to cut deaths. But we cannot wait for that either.The lockdown must be gradually lted, starting next month, before further catastrophic damage is done to our economy, our society and the long-term health of our nation.We must continue to shield the most vulnerable and prevent a devastating second wave of infections overwhelming the NHS in a way the first did not.And we must deploy whatever weapons we have to slow Covid-.Masks at work, in shops and on public transport  Fine. Let’s wear them.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eating burgers sausages dementia
story: Processed meats are often eaten with other unhealthy nosh, combining to damage the brain, they say.The junk foods contain harmful preservatives and lead to greater consumption of other grub bad for grey matter.These include starchy products such as spuds, bread, rice, pasta, biscuits and cakes.The findings are based on a study of more than  over-s in south-western France, around a third of whom had dementia.Lead author Dr Cecilia Samieri, of the University of Bordeaux, said: “People who developed dementia were more likely to combine highly processed meats such as sausages, cured meats and pâté with starchy foods like potatoes, alcohol and snacks like cookies and cakes.“People without dementia were more likely to accompany meat with more erse foods, including fruit and veg and seafood.”It has been known for years that a healthy diet rich in unprocessed foods can boost mental powers. The latest study suggests it is the way foods are eaten together that is linked to dementia risk.In the UK, there are , people with dementia, set to rise to two million by  because of the ageing population.Dr Samieri added: “How foods are consumed — and not only the quantity consumed — may be important for dementia prevention.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: department health not publicise ppe turkey
story: THE Department of Health warned Downing Street not to publicise a PPE shipment in case there were problems, it was reported.An RAF plane sent to pick up the -tonne consignment of personal protective equipment from Turkey arrived back in the UK on Wednesday morning.The Government has faced intense criticism over shortages of PPE for medical staff battling the coronavirus pandemic.Ministers raised hopes by promising , badly needed surgical gowns would arrive from Turkey on Sunday but they failed to arrive that day.A source toldHealth Secretary Matt Hancock’s cabinet colleague Robert Jenrick was “strongly advised” not to mention the consignment in case there were problems.But with the approval of Downing Street, the housing, communities and local government secretary went ahead anyway and told last Saturday’ coronavirus media briefing. “We strongly advised Robert Jenrick against doing this but he and No  overruled us,” the Department of Health and Social Care source said.“The advice we gave as a department was that we shouldn’t mention inidual orders of PPE. But for whatever reason it wasn’t followed.”It isnt known, surgical gowns were on board the plane, but three pallets were seen being unloaded after it landed.The shortage of gowns is one of the most urgent problems, as the NHS goes through , a day.Health chiefs have repeatedly warned supplies of PPE are critically low and medics could be forced to work without them in hours.The Government has been desperately trying to source the protective fear from around the globe as the Covid- crisis rages.It has been accused of wasting time in ramping up domestic production of PPE, after failing to respond to manufacturers offers to help make medical gowns for a month.Several domestic companies, with the capability to make medical-grade PPE, offered to make millions of masks, but by the time they got a response they had sold the equipment to other countries.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: swedens parks bars packed coronavirus
story: SWEDENS parks, bars and restaurants remain packed, despite its daily coronavirus death toll continuing to soar.Shocking photos taken in the capital of Stockholm on Wednesday show bustling scenes as le carries on as normal amid the deadly outbreak.Sweden is the only country in Europe not to have imposed lockdowns - even though its death toll is worse than USA, Iran and Germany when compared to population sizeIts a move which has sparked criticism from scientists and medics who have warned it will lead to catastrophe.The Scandinavian country recorded  new deaths and  new cases yesterday.The deaths were the second-largest jump on record, lagging only behind Tuesdays figure of .It takes the death toll in Sweden to ,.That is far higher than its neighbours Denmark , Norwayand Finland .But its still far lower than the number killed in the UKwhich introduced lockdown measures on March .The  infections recorded brought the total to , which was the biggest daily rise for nearly two weeks.But health officials believe the virus may have peaked in the capital - where it is believed up to a third of people had contracted the virus by May .Research hints the rate of new infections peaked in Stockholm on April , which some believe means the herd immunity approach to tackling the virus is working.Stockholm currently accounts for more than half of the countrys total deaths.Anders Wallensten, deputy state epidemiologist, said: Already a bit more than a week ago, the peak was reached, at least according to this model, and we can expect fewer cases each day.But he added: You also have to remember ... that two-thirds have not been infected and can still get it.Wallensten said the advantage of Swedens low-key approach is that advisory measures can be kept in place for longer than with a total lockdown.Gatherings of more than  people have been banned along with visits to nursing homes, but otherwise social distancing is advised rather than enforced.Officials say that people in Sweden have a high level of trust in government agencies meaning that advisory measures have been widely followed.Swedens neighbour Denmark is now reopening schools for children aged  and under from tomorrow, but other restrictions remain until May .It was announced earlier that Sweden shut down the last of its Chinese state-sponsored teaching programmes as relations between the two countries continue to sour.According to the Times, Sweden is believed to be the first European state to close all its Confucius institutes and classrooms, which teach Chinese language and culture with textbooks and funding from Beijing.Analysts have regarded the closure as a sign that the relationship between the two countries is unravelling amid accusations of bullying, meddling and incompetence.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: welsh politician swore zoom app
story: Vaughan Gething could be heard saying What the f**k is the matter with her  while moaning about Cardf Central Assembly Member Jenny Rathbone.The blundering Labour politician had accidentally left his microphone on during the virtual Welsh Assembly session on the Zoom video app yesterday.Shocked colleagues could be seen gaping open-mouthed during the gaffe, while others just nervously laughed.Mr Gething has since apologised for his behaviour, which took place as Labour politician Ms Rathbone asked questions about the governments response to coronavirus in Wales.He tweeted: Im obviously embarrassed about my comments at the end of questions today. Ive sent a message apologising and offered to speak to Jenny Rathboneshe wishes to do so.It is an unwelcome distraction at a time of unprecedented challenge.The footage shows Mr Gething turning the air blue after ending his own contribution to the meeting - but he forgot to mute his microphone.Fellow members urged him to stop as Ms Rathbone could be seen getting off her seat and walking off camera.Some opposition parties have now called for Mr Gething to be sacked over the blunder.Adam Price, leader of Plaid Cymru, said: The Health Minister has not only failed over the last month several times, he has failed to acknowledge that he has failed and aggressively attacks even those within his own party who question him.He does not have the right attitude, skills or temperament to lead the Governments response to the coronavirus pandemic.To maintain public confidence the First Minister needs to relieve him of these responsibilities with immediate effect.The Welsh Liberal Democrats added in a statement: He should not have made those remarks, whether his microphone was muted or not.However, we all need to be focusing on what is most important – tackling this deadly pandemic by ensuring we increase testing and give families and businesses the support they need.Video streaming app Zoom has landed a string of users in hot water after it gained popularity during coronavirus lockdown.Earlier this month, trolls gatecrashed a council meeting being broadcast on the app by playing porn and swearing at members of staff.South Somerset District Councils planning committee held its first virtual meeting — with the public able to log in and watch proceedings.But their deliberations were soon plagued by a number of rude interruptions — and at one point audio from a porn film could be heard playing in the background.And in March, a woman was left red-faced after accidentally filming herself on the toilet during a video conference.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: shoppers bq open coronavirus lockdown
story: THOUSANDS of shoppers are today queuing outside BQ after the chain reopened  stores during the coronavirus lockdown.Hundreds were seen queuing outside a store in Ashfield, Notts, with people keen to carry out refurbishments while they stay at home.Others were seen buying plants and gardening tools from a BQ in Leeds while pictures showed more cars on motorways this morning.Meanwhile, one group of lads ignored social distancing rules to play football in Londons Southwark Park.The picture caused concern for one minister who said there is a risk people are starting to ignore the rules.MP Brandon Lewis told of his fears people will be struggling to stick to the lockdown after so many weeks cooped up inside.He said: I think there is always a risk when you are doing something like this, particularly those living alone, will be finding it really dficult.Weve got to look at the success weve had in flattening that curve. Weve lost too many lives already.When you follow the guidelines, when you stay home, you are doing something directly personally that is not just helping the NHS, but saving lives.BQ had been closed since the end of March since the introduction of lockdown measures to try to contain the spread of Covid-.Customers had been able to use click and collect services to purchase goods after hardware stores were included on the governments list of essential retailers.The store carried out a trial in  stores over the weekend and opened them fully - with restrictions.It today opened a further  stores and pictures show Brits following rules as they patiently queue to enter.A BQ spokesperson said: As an essential retailer, we’re committed to providing the best possible service to support customers’ home improvement needs at this dficult time, while keeping customers and colleagues safe.Having watched other essential retailers support social distancing in their stores, we are now following their best practice and are re-opening some stores with strict social distancing measures in place.Similar to shopping at a supermarket, we’re strictly limiting the number of customers in store at any one time, and so customers are typically queueing before entering stores.All stores have a designated queuing area outside and these have two metre markers to help remind everyone to respect each other’s personal space.To further support social distancing, we have two metre floor markers throughout the store and have also installed perspex screens at the checkouts.We’re urging all customers to follow the Government’s social distancing guidelines, to shop responsibly only for what is necessary and to be patient whilst we give them the best possible service in the safest possible way.The warm and sunny weather has made coronavirus lockdown even harder for Brits, with it forecast to be hotter than Lanzerote today and tomorrow.It brings fears the temperature will be too tempting for some as the weekend arrives at the end of five weeks of being stuck indoors.Most of the country will enjoy the balmy weather, with temperatures hitting C in Wales and C in Scotland.The shocked journalist who saw the footballers in Burgess Park yesterday tweeted: Not surprising that Southwark is one of the worst-hit London boroughs from #COVID. Out for my walk in Burgess Park today and there’s people sunbathing, drinking in groups and even a -a-side football game ongoing - the worst I’ve seen it in lockdown.As the death toll hit , yesterday, Hyde Park in London was packed with young Brits exercising, while a group of paramedics were seen enjoying a well-deserved break in the sunshine.In the government press conference, it was announced that traffic on Britains roads is beginning to increase during lockdown.Graphs show all motor vehicle traffic spike since yesterday - the first signicant rise since April .Housebuilder Taylor Wimpey said it plans to resume work on its construction sites from May , after ordering its sites, show homes and sales centres to be closed in March.Meanwhile, shoppers at The Range in Southampton, Hants, were seen loading up with supplies yesterday - some which could be deemed non-essential - to help keep them occupied while they stay at home.Some shoppers were seen bringing trolley loads of non-essential gardening materials, plants and compost back to their cars as Britain basks in warm weather.Under the rules to stop the spread of the virus, people can only leave home for a limited number of reasons:Chris Whitty admitted lockdown measures will be needed until the end of the year to control coronavirus - until a drug or a vaccine is round.The Chief Medical Officer said that some form of the measures Britain is going to have to be in place for a long period of time to make sure the transmission rate doesnt grow and begin toIt was wholly unrealistic to think ato normal le is possible anytime soon, Mr Whitty told the Downing Street press conference this evening.There will be a series of choices and ministers will decide a mix of measures to try and get back to a new normal.The only exit from lockdown will be a vaccine or drugs to treat coronavirus, he said.Strict social distancing measures introduced last month to help tackle the spread of the deadly bug say Brits should only leave home to shop for basic necessities like food or medicine.But there is confusion at guidance on what is a reasonable excuse to leave your home during the UKs Covid- shutdown.On March , Prime Minister Boris Johnson ordered all non-essential shops to shut while urging Brits to stay at home to stop the spread of coronavirus.The government is now under pressure to explain to Brits how and when the coronavirus lockdown will end.The Cabinet is now said to be split into “doves and hawks” over how and when to end the UK-wide shutdown, which is ravaging the countrys economy.Some ministers are said to be against ending the lockdown too early to avoid a second wave, while others want to lt it to avoid a bigger economic crisis.And guidance from senior police leaders issued last week on what is permitted has confused many.The National Police Chiefs Counciland College of Policings three-page document laid out reasonable excuses to leave home.They advised that buying paint and brushes, simply to redecorate a kitchen was not likely to be reasonable.But the advice, which is to help police officers interpret the lockdown rules, says buying tools and supplies  to repair a fence  is likely to be reasonable.Brits are allowed to sit down for a moment to catch their breath or eat their lunch, but onlythey are on a long walk.A short walk to a park bench, when the person remains seated for a much longer period is not considered reasonable, the rules say.The new guidance come after accusations of over-zealous policing of Brits. Downing Street slapped down policing tactics, saying stores are “free to sell what they stock” after officers from Cambridge Police patrolled “non-essential aisles” for shoppers.A police force had to apologise after one of its officers told a family they couldnt use their own front garden.Northamptonshire Police Chief Constable Nick Adderley was forced to backtrack after saying cops could start to marshal supermarkets and check the items in baskets.He said the public had enjoyed a three-week grace period and said his force would slap fines and arrest those caught outside for non-essential reasons.He said: We will not, at this stage, be setting up road blocks.We will not, at this stage, start to marshal supermarkets and check the items in baskets and trolleys to see whether its a necessary item.But be under no illusion,people do not heed the warnings and the pleas Im making today, we will start to do that.Home Secretary Priti Patel has repeatedly refused to give in to police chiefs demands for even more
